title: Are there substances that have a pH of 0? - Quora

response.answer_text: To answer this you have to understand what pH means. It’s a mathematical formula, pH=−log(H+)pH=−log(H+). As a result of this, this means we can calculate the necessary concentration of H+H+ to equal 0. When the equation is solved, we find that the concentration of H+H+ must be 1 M. As some strong acids can be dissolved in water at a concentration greater than 1 M (including hydrochloric acid), a solution can have a pH of 0. Note that I said concentration, pH is a measure of concentration, it’s not an intrinsic property of a substance. pH only ever makes sense if we’re talking about a solution of some substance dissolved in water*. So, for this example, hydrochloric acid does not have a pH of 0, I can make a solution of hydrochloric acid to have a pH between ~-1 to <7, depending upon how much I add to water. *It can also make sense with pure water, I guess.

Yes. Not only are there substances with a pH of zero, but there are substance that have a pH < 0. I have given an example in a previous answer; feel free to take a look! pH is a function of concentration of hydronium ions in solution, which in turn is a function of the concentration of acid, and the strength of that acid. A 1 mol/L solution of a strong monoprotic acid such as HCl will have a pH of 0. The pH scale doesn’t have hard limits at 0 (though there will be physical constraints, obviously), the pH of concentrated H2SO4 will be -1.3, for example.

No - substances have no pH - the concept of pH applies only to solutions. This said, to have a pH = 0 a solution should have a very high concentration of H+ - so high that it deviates from ideality. Thus a solution of, say, 1 M HCl does not have a pH of 0, but somewhat higher.

Sure pH of zero is possible it just requires a concentration of 1M of H+. That is 1 mole of hydrogen ions per litre of solute. This is because pH is defined as the decimal logarithm of the reciprocal of the hydrogen ion activity, aH+, in a solution. Note the concentration of hydrogen ions can be even higher than this in some cases resulting in a negative pH like in superacids like Fluoroantimonic acid which has a pH of -31.3

No there isn’t any substance that has pH = 0, pH = 0 will mean -log([H+]) = 0, i.e [H+] = 1 and we know practically no substance, even a strong acid like HCl or HNO3 can dissociate completely to fully release a proton
